questions.question: Question 1: Which among the following is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults?
questions.explanation: Malignant melanoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in adults. Retinoblastoma is the most common primary intraocular malignancy in children.

questions.question: Question 2: Which is the most common primary malignant tumor of the lid?
questions.explanation: The most common primary malignant tumor of the lid is basal cell carcinoma. The second most common tumor of the lid is squamous cell carcinoma

questions.question:
Question 3: Which of the following is the most common lid malignancy in HIV patients? 534 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Kaposi sarcoma is the commonest malignancy of the lid and conjunctiva in HIV patients. It appears as a violaceous non-tender nodule on the eyelid or conjunctiva. It is a rapidly growing 
acquired neoplasm composed of malignant stromal cells densely vascularized by blood vessels of 
capillary size. The typical lesion appears as an expanding, bright red subepithelial mass that projects through 
and replaces the overlying conjunctival epithelium. Spontaneous bleeding leading to bloody tears 
or a subconjunctival hematoma is relatively common. Conjunctival Kaposi’s sarcoma can be treated by excision, cryotherapy, radiation therapy (external 
beam or contact therapy), chemotherapy, or topical or intralesional interferon-.

questions.question:
Question 4: Which of the following cannot be used in the management of the clinical condition shown 
below?
questions.explanation:
The image shows a capillary hemangioma involving the left upper lid and periocular area. 
Interferon beta is not used in the management of capillary hemangioma. However, note that 
interferon alfa-2a is used in resistant cases. A capillary haemangioma is the most common tumor of the orbit and periorbital area in 
childhood. It may present as small isolated lesions or large masses that can cause visual impairment (due to 
mechanical ptosis and the resulting sensory deprivation amblyopia), systemic effects (severe 
thrombocytopenia), or exist as part of PHACE syndrome (Posterior fossa anomalies, 
Hemangioma, Arterial lesions, Cardiac abnormalities, Eye or Endocrine abnormalities) 30% of lesions resolve by the age of 3 years and about 75% by the age of 7. Indications for treatment are: • Visual (amblyopia, astigmatism, occlusion, strabismus) 542 
Sold by @itachibot • Cosmesis • Optic nerve compression • Exposure keratopathy Treatment options include: • Beta blockers- oral propranolol, topical timolol. • Steroids- intralesional triamcinolone or betamethasone, topical clobetasol, systemic steroids. • Interferon alfa-2a and vincristine- for steroid-resistant sight-threatening lesions • Local resection with cutting cautery or carbon dioxide laser.

questions.question:
Question 5: An 8-year old child presented with right-sided proptosis. Biopsy of the orbital mass was done 
and histopathological examination revealed this picture. What is the most likely diagnosis? 535 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The most likely diagnosis is rhabdomyosarcoma (RMS). Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common 
soft tissue sarcoma of childhood. 40% of rhabdomyosarcomas develop in the head and neck, and they are the most common 
primary orbital malignancy in children but are still a rare condition. The older age of the child 
presenting with proptosis suggests rhabdomyosarcoma (average age 7 to 8 years) than 
retinoblastoma (average age at presentation is 18 months). The histopathology shows elongated to round spindle cells with features of skeletal muscle at 
different stages of maturation with highly eosinophilic cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei – the 
embryonal type of rhabdomyosarcoma Immunohistochemistry is useful in identifying skeletal muscle proteins, such as alpha-actin, 
myosin, desmin, and myoglobin Rhabdomyosarcoma shows a strong tendency for local invasion, local recurrence, and 
hematogenous and lymphatic metastases. Decision-making for management is based on histopathologic confirmation as well as the staging 
of orbital RMS, which includes imaging (MRI of primary tumor, chest-CT, Tc bone scan), 
pathology, and work-up for metastases(bone marrow biopsy). Treatment options include chemotherapy (vincristine, cyclophosphamide, and actinomycin D) and 
radiotherapy.

questions.question:
Question 6: A patient presented with painless decrease in vision and metamorphopsia. Fundus 
examination revealed the lesion shown in the image. What is the expected finding on 
angiography?
questions.explanation:
The clinical vigenette is of a patient presenting with painless dimunition of vision and 
metamorphopsia with the right fundus showing choroidal melanoma superotemporal to the optic 
disc and involving the macula. In this patient a “Double circulation” pattern consisting of an internal circulation within the lesion 
and the normal vascularity of the overlying retina will be seen on angiography. 543 
Sold by @itachibot Although collar stud(Option C) appearance is pathagnomic for choroidal melanoma, it can be seen 
on B-scan and not on angiography. Choroidal melanoma is a primary intraocular malignancy in adults that peaks around 60 years of 
age. Symptoms include a range of visual disturbances such as painless decrease in vision and 
metamorphosia when macula is involved. Other features of Choroidal melanoma includes: • A solitary elevated subretinal grey-brown dome shaped mass • Clumps of orange pigment are common over the mass • Collar stud appearance on B-scan (option C): It is pathagnomic of choridal melanoma. It is seen 
if the tumour breaks through the Bruch's membrane into the subretinal space . • Associated haemorrhage Smoke stack pattern (option A) and ink blot (option B) pattern is seen on FFA in central serous 
retinopathy (CSR). CSR is the spontaneous serous detachment of the sensory neuroretina in the foveal region with or 
without retinal pigment epithelium (RPE) detachment. This occurs due Choroidal vascular hyperpermeability. On FFA it is initially seen as an ink-blot pattern or smoke stack pattern 
of hyperfluorescence which then spreads to take the configuration 
of mushroom or umbrella pattern. The below given images depict the smoke stack pattern and mushroom pattern respectively 544 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: A 68-year-old man presents with jaundice. He was recently diagnosed with malignant 
melanoma of the uvea but did not receive proper treatment due to the prevalent pandemic 
situation. Investigations reveal liver secondaries. What would be the ideal line of 
management?
questions.explanation:
The spread of malignant melanoma of the uvea outside the orbit is treated with enucleation + 
chemotherapy + immunotherapy. Orbital spread of the malignant melanoma necessitates exenteration but metastasis elsewhere can 
be treated by enucleation, chemotherapy, and immunotherapy.

questions.question:
Question 8: A father has noticed that his child's left pupil appears white as shown below. Worried about 
this, the father consults an ophthalmologist. All of the following should be included in the 
differential diagnosis except:
questions.explanation:
The child has leukocoria and congenital glaucoma is not to be included in the differential 
diagnosis. Various conditions, other than retinoblastoma, which present as leukocoria are collectively called 
pseudoglioma. Differential diagnosis of leukocoria: • Retinoblastoma • Congenital cataract • Coloboma of the choroid • Persistent hyperplastic primary vitreous • Toxocara infestation • Norrie disease • Coat's exudative retinopathy Intraocular pressure (IOP) is usually raised in retinoblastoma and lowered in pseudoglioma. 545 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 9: Retinoblastoma arises from which of the following structures?
questions.explanation:
Retinoblastoma (also called glioma retinae) arises from the neurosensory retina. It is 
a proliferation of neural cells that have failed to evolve normally. Tumours are composed of small basophilic cells (retinoblasts), with large hyperchromatic nuclei 
and scanty cytoplasm. It is of 4 types: • Endophytic (into the vitreous) with seeding of tumor cells throughout the eye • Exophytic (into the subretinal space) leading to retinal detachment • Mixed type • Retinocytoma: retina may be diffusely infiltrated

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is the most common clinical presentation of retinoblastoma?
questions.explanation:
The most common clinical presentation of retinoblastoma is leukocoria plus strabismus. Clinical features of retinoblastoma: • Present within the first two years of life • Leukocoria • Strabismus • Painful red eye with secondary glaucoma • Orbital inflammation mimicking orbital or pre-septal cellulitis. • Orbital invasion or visible extraocular growth may occur in neglected cases. • Metastatic disease involving regional lymph nodes and the brain before the detection of ocular 
involvement is rare. Signs: • An intraretinal tumor is a homogeneous, dome-shaped white lesion that becomes irregular, often 
with white flecks of calcification. • An endophytic tumor projects into the vitreous as a white mass that may "seed" into the gel. • An exophytic tumor forms multilobular subretinal white masses and causes an overlying retinal 
detachment. Investigations: • Red reflex testing with a direct ophthalmoscope is a simple screening test for leukocoria. • Dilated fundus examination using indirect ophthalmoscope • MRI of the orbit + brain 546 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: A 3-year-old boy was brought by his parents with concern about being increasingly clumsy for 
the past 6 months. On examination, there is leukocoria with an absence of the red reflex in 
the left eye. As further workup reveals a tumor, the eye is enucleated and the microscopic 
appearance is as shown in the image. Molecular analysis of the tumor indicates loss of cell 
cycle control in the tumor cells. Where is the responsible gene located? 538 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The histology showing Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes and clinical history of white reflex point 
towards a diagnosis of retinoblastoma. Retinoblastoma is due to mutation in Rb gene located on 
chromosome 13q14. Retinoblastoma was first cancer known to be directly associated with a genetic abnormality. The HPE image below shows Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes, the clustering of small blue cuboidal 
or short columnar cells around a central lumen.

questions.question: Question 12: Knudson's two-hit hypothesis describes the occurrence of which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Knudson's two-hit hypothesis describes the occurrence of retinoblastoma. Knudson's hypothesis can be stated as follows: • Two mutations (hits), involving both alleles of RB are required to produce retinoblastoma. • In familial retinoblastoma, one of the pair of alleles of RB1 is mutated in all the cells of the body. 
When a further mutagenic event ("second hit" according to the "two-hit" hypothesis proposed by 
Knudson) affects the second allele, the cell may then undergo malignant transformation. A large 
majority of these children develop bilateral and multifocal tumors. • In sporadic cases, both RB alleles must undergo somatic mutation in the same retinoblast (two 
hits). Familial retinoblastoma patients also have a predisposition to non-ocular cancers because of the 
presence of the mutation in all cells, such as pinealoblastoma (usually before the age of 5 years), 
osteosarcomas, soft tissue sarcomas, and melanomas. Note: 547 
Sold by @itachibot Trilateral retinoblastoma = Pinealoblastoma + Bilateral retinoblastoma

questions.question: Question 15: What is the treatment of choice when retinoblastoma involves the optic nerve?
questions.explanation:
Optic nerve involvement is treated by enucleation + adjuvant chemotherapy + radiotherapy Indications for enucleation [Group E tumor - according to the International Classification of 
Retinoblastoma (ICRB)]: • Tumor involves more than half of the retina • Optic nerve involved • Glaucoma is present and the anterior chamber is involved Chemotherapy commonly used is a three-drug regimen containing vincristine, carboplatin, and 
etoposide.

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following regimen is commonly used■ in the treatment of retinoblastoma?
questions.explanation:
Chemotherapy commonly used is a three-drug regimen containing vincristine, carboplatin, and 
etoposide.

questions.question: Question 17: What is the treatment of choice for anterior lesions of retinoblastoma?
questions.explanation: Cryotherapy is used for anterior lesions of retinoblastoma. Photocoagulation for posterior lesions of retinoblastoma.

questions.question:
Question 18: The most common secondaries in choroid are from  
.
questions.explanation:
The most common secondaries in choroid originate from the breast (overall and in females), and 
lungs (in males). 549
